title: A Busy End to the Semester and Start of Summer
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
QUARTERLY UPDATE | Apr to Jun 2025

Undergraduate Research Sucesses | Another year has come to a close. We had many undergraduate poster presentations at the end of this year. Kristine and Conner both presented their posters at the 2025 OSU Undergraduate Research Symposium at the ConocoPhillips Alumni Center. They also presented thier work at the Karen L. Smith Undergraduate Symposium hosted by our Department in Life Sciences West.

Additionally, Savannah capped off her prestigious year-long Wentz Research Scholarship with a presentation at the Wentz Research Symposium in the Student Union Ballroom. Savannah graduated this semester and will be pursuing a career in wildlife conservation.

We graduate another fantastic undergraduate researcher, Mady. She was admitted to the Clinical Laboratory Sciences Program at the OSU Center for Health Sciences in Tulsa.

All of my undergraduate resaerchers have done a fantastic job this year!

Kristine presenting her research at the Karen L. Smith Undergraduate Research Symposium.

Conner presenting his research at the Karen L. Smith Undergraduate Research Symposium.

Welcoming Susanne | Susanne Hahs is joining us for an M.S. after recently graduating from Boston College. She will be working on the functional evolution of receptors in the HPI axis.

Susanne was originally supposed to be joining us as an NSF RaMP Fellow and work in the lab as a full-time researcher for the next year. However, our multi-year NSF RaMP Program grant in the department was abruptly terminated. The reach of these historic cuts to science is enormous, and even our labs here in the more conservative-leaning states and public universities are being hit hard as well. The NSF RaMP Program was a highly impactful program for training the next generation of scientists, and our program has brought many jobs to Stillwater. It has been sad to see it end too early.

Luckily, we were still able to take Susanne on as a graduate student. I am thrilled to have someone in the lab working on receptor evolution! So, we will be firing back up the luciferase reporter gene assay that I used to run a lot at the University of Denver as an NSF Fellow. We are really starting to assemble lots of different tools in the lab now.

A Full Lab this Summer | This summer, the Shaughnessy Lab has 6 people working in the lab on research assistantships, all 5 graduate students and 1 undergraduate student, Samantha Kennedy. We were able to get the whole lab (and partners/spouses) together for dinner at our house. Looking forward to a summer of productivity with this team!

Lab dinner at Ciaran's house.

NASCE | Allison and I traveled to Québec City for the North American Society of Comparative Endocrinologists (NASCE) meeting. It was wonderful bringing a student along to a conference. The science and socializing were fantastic, as they always are at NASCE. The poutine was... interesting, as it always is in Quebec. We brought home lots of good ideas. Of course, I brought back some maple-flavored lollipops for my toddler at home.

Ciaran and Allison attended NASCE 2025 in Québec City.

title: Functionally divergent melanocortin receptor subtypes and the HPI axis in sea lamprey
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
New Paper in J Mol Endocrinol! This was my first time putting our work in this journal and I think it is a really nice fit. JME a great, society-run journal, and the peer review process was engaging and constructive. I'm going to be sending more work to this journal.

Functionally divergent melanocortin receptor subtypes and the HPI axis in sea lamprey

J Mol Endocrinol, 2025

Shaughnessy CA, Myhre VD, McCormick SD, Dores RM

PDF

title: A Cftr-independent, Ano1-rich seawater-adaptive ionocyte in sea lamprey gills
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
I cannot describe how relieved I am to have this work out there finally. I have been working on this manuscript since 2018! It is a challenging paper because its most predominant finding is essentially a negative result, the lack of a mechanism for salt-secretion in lamprey that is present in all other marine fishes. I'm glad it found a good home in JEB.

A Cftr-independent, Ano1-rich seawater-adaptive ionocyte in sea lamprey gills

J Exp Biol, 2025

Shaughnessy CA, Hall DJ, Norstog JL, Ferreira-Martins D, Barany A, Regish AM, Breves JP, Komoroske LM, McCormick SD

PDF

title: New Arrivals: Graduate Students and Sea Lamprey
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
QUARTERLY UPDATE | Jan to Mar 2025

Welcome to Ava | I am very excited to have Ava Cannizzaro join our lab from the University of Denver. She will be putting together a project to follow up with my work characterizing the molecular mechanisms of the SW-type ionocyte in the lamprey gills. Fun fact: Ava was a student of mine in the 'Physiological Systems' class I taught at DU while I was an NSF Fellow there.

Welcome to Madison | Madison Merideth is joining our lab as an M.S. student. She received her B.S. in Psycology at OSU and has been conducting undergraduate research in the McCullagh Lab. She will be pioneering some of the graduate-level CF work in the lab. We'll be putting together a project to identify a novel GPCR-mediated pathway for CFTR activation on the airway epithelium.

Welcome Sea Lamprey | It wouldn't be a Shaughnessy Lab without some lamprey. We've got the anadromous strain joining us from the Connecticut River in Massachusetts (thanks to our collaborator Amy Regish at the USGS Conte Lab) and from Hammond Bay Biological Station in Michigan (thanks to several folks there).

Sea lamprey acclimating in the new tanks.

title: Physiological and morphological traits affect contemporary range expansion in an amphibian species
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
I was happy to play a minor part of this manuscript of Owen's, who is a recently graduated M.S. student from Dr. Bo Zhang's lab here in the Department. We are pursuing funding to follow this up and have submitted an NSF grant to investigate the causal link between plasticity in minimum thermal tolerance and northward range expansion in amphibians.

Physiological and morphological traits affect contemporary range expansion and implications for species distribution modeling in an amphibian species

J Anim Ecol, 2025

Edwards OM, Reichert MS, Ozmen L, Shaughnessy CA, Zhai L, Zhang B

PDF

title: The Aquatics Lab is Active and Full of Killifish
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
QUARTERLY UPDATE | Oct to Dec 2024

Aqautics Lab | A lot of my early attention has been in establishing our ability to run whole-organism experiments in the lab, which means building out an Aquatics facility from scratch and gettin the IACUC approvals in place. Finally, we are at a point we have a fully operational wet lab, with 2 300-gal tanks, 5 racks of experimental tanks, and the all the temperature regualtory, aeration, and filtration mechanisms in place.

Arrival of Killifish | We had our first arrivals of Atlantic killifish (Fundulus heteroclitus) to the lab. They are from New Hampshire, and hardy New Englanders like me.

Year-End Recap | Looking back on this year, its hard what to make off it. This was my first year as faculty. Tremendously busy, but not all that productive (based on the metrics I have so far been measuring my productivity). I taught a new course; I built an aquatics lab and a lab for cell culture and molecular biolgy; I have had many undergradutes working in the lab and have taken on my first PhD students; I submitted many grants that went unfunded. Still, I only published one first author publication (a book chapter) and contributed to a couple other papers (thanks to Jason Breves). This publication prodoctivity is far less than recent years... folks tell me it will be this way at the beginning of a new faculty appointment, but it is still unsatisfying. We have some exciting new papers and grants in review right now, and I am looking forward to a more productive year next year.

Wetlab racks prior to arrival of fish.

title: Salinity and prolactin regulate anoctamin 1 in killifish
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
It was a pleasure being involved with Jason's findings of Ano1 in the killifish gill. The story that is unfolding about ano1 in the sw-type ionocyte is interesting and unexpected. I'm curious to see where it takes us...

Salinity and prolactin regulate anoctamin 1 in the model teleost, Fundulus heteroclitus

Am J Physiol Regul Integr Comp Physiol, 2024

Breves JP, Posada M, Tao Y, Shaughnessy CA

PDF

title: Welcome to the First Graduate Students in the Shaughnessy Lab
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
QUARTERLY UPDATE | Jul to Sep 2024

Welcome to Allison and Dillon | This Fall, Allison DeLoache (B.S., Clemson Univ; M.S., Southeastern LA Univ) and Dillon Flowers (B.S., Weber St Univ; M.S. UT Tyler) joined the lab as PhD students after completing their Master's degrees elsewhere. Allison will be working on environmental and chronic stress physiology, and already has a project lined up with ODWC to compare thermal tolerance of introduced and native smallmouth bass. Dillon will be working on intestinal ion transport processes in the intestine of marine fishes (including, of course, sea lamprey).

ISFE | Also, in the early Fall, I attended the International Symposium on Fish Endocrinology in Baltimore, MD, put on by the International Society of Fish Endocrinologists, of which I am on the International Governing Committee. It was nice to see my comparative endocrinology colleagues in Baltimore!

title: Savannah Wentz Scholarship and New Undergraduates
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
QUARTERLY UPDATE | Apr to Jun 2024

Undergradutes in the Lab | This Spring, I have had my first undergraduate students at OSU join me in the lab and it has been a blast. Although progress was slow, their presence really helped us dive in and get some of the basic molecular biology assays going on in the lab.

Congrats, Savannah! | An undergraduate in my lab, Savannah Caldwell, has been awarded a prestigous Wentz Research Scholarship to set up airway cell cutlure and being our investigations into novel mechanisms for receptor-mediate activation of CFTR.

ICBF | This June, I attended the International Congress on the Biology of Fish in Ann Arbor, MI. This has always been my favorite conference. As I am now the treasurer of the AFS Physiology Section (the society that puts on ICBF), the conference is a bit more work, but still great fun. The science is always good!

title: Endocrine control of gill ionocyte function in euryhaline fishes
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
It was a great honor to be asked to write the review article on endocrine control of ionocytes. This was part of a special issue that was a 20-year anniversary update to the Multifunctional Fish Gill paper by Evans et al. Some great physiologists contributed to this special issue in JCP.

Endocrine control of gill ionocyte function in euryhaline fishes

J Comp Physiol B, 2024

Breves JP, Shaughnessy CA

PDF

title: Ion Regulation in Anadromous Fishes (Book Chapter)
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
I was happy to be asked to write a book chapter for the Encyclopedia of Fish Physiology. It was a joy writing this chapter with my M.S. supervisor, Jason Bystriansky. Now, if only I had $2,000 to buy the book. Purchase here.

Ion Regulation in Anadromous Fishes

Encyclopedia of Fish Physiology (2nd Edition), 2024

Shaughnessy CA, Bystriansky JS

PDF

title: New Lab, New Course, New Everthing
author: Ciaran Shaughnessy
content:
QUARTERLY UPDATE | Jan to Mar 2024

New Beginnings | My faculty appointment at OSU has officially begun. I've got several undergraduates in the lab and I've started teaching a large, upper-level physiology course. There is a lot to do before we start running experiments, generating data, and being awarded funding at the level I am hoping for. I'm looking forward to the work and getting to know many wonderful scientists at all levels of their career through this journey here at OSU!
